content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are provided a markdown document `md` with julia language code blocks. Write a function `extract_julia_code` that extracts all the code blocks, removes code fences and joins the code blocks (if there are multiple) together with a newline. Return a String. Do not provide any examples.

```julia
function extract_julia_code(md::String)::String
    # Regular expression to match Julia language code blocks with or without line numbers
    julia_code_block = r"```julia(?:\n[^\n]*)?\n([^`]*\n*)"m
    
    # Initialize an empty string to store the extracted code
    extracted_code = ""
    
    # Split the markdown document into lines
    lines = split(md, '\n')
    
    # Iterate over each line in the document
    for (i, line) in enumerate(lines)
        # If the line matches the Julia code block regex
        m = match(julia_code_block, line)
        if m !== nothing
            # If it's a new code block, append the previous extracted code to the result
            if i > 1 && extracted_code != ""
                extracted_code *= '\n'
            end
            
            # Append the line without the code fences
            extracted_code *= replace(line, r"^```julia\n|```$" => "")
        end
    end
    
    return extracted_code
end
```

This function uses a regular expression to match Julia code blocks, which are defined by triple backticks and the `julia` language identifier. It then iterates over each line in the markdown document and appends the content of the code block (without the opening and closing code fences) to the extracted code string. If the line is not part of a code block, it is ignored. Finally, the function returns the joined code blocks as a single string with newlines between them.
